column4: After installing ubuntu 7.10 i got "GRUB Loading stage 1.5 read error" when trying to boot, I found this solution http://ubuntuforums.org/archive/index.php/t-615668.html , following it when booted from live cd ,but when I try to execute this command "root (hdx,y) setup (hdx) quit" I get message "Error 11: Unrecognized device string", also after doing "gksudo gedit /boot/grub/menu.lst" the file opens but it's empty ? any ideas o
bump, anyone ?
the error you are getting is prolly cause your arguments to grub aren't correct ...i.e. (hdX, Y)
grub starts numbering drives and partitions from 0...not from 1 like linux does
so if you are trying to install grub on 1st partition of 1st harddisk...you would do setup(hd0,0)
oh it didnt give me any error this time writing setup(hd0,0) but nothing's happening, what should be my next step ? sorry to bother you mate : )
well just follow the same instructions to the post in that link you posted...except make sure that you have your numbering scheme correct.
Checking if "/boot/grub/stage1" exists... yes
http://paste.ubuntu.com/27158/ thats what i got
I don't know exactly what your setup is...but your earlier problem was due to incorrect number usage...i still think that you are not providing the proper argument
paste sudo fdisk -l
http://paste.ubuntu.com/27159/
what partition are you trying to install inux.
*linux

there are 2 ways you can install grub on  a driver...first one is to go into grubshell. and do setup..root and all that stuff..........another option, which i prefer to use is grub-install from linux command linux..."grub-install" does a lot of things for you automatically...the only thing you need to do is provide it with (hdX) of the harddisk you are trying to install it upon.
please post your /boot/grub/menu.lst file
that doesnt tell me much, damn im so terrible heh...
xorg
sorry, that was not intended for you....i get a lil confused trying to help out 2 ppl at once..sorry
xorg ?
yes, and after do xserver-xorg
make sure you "sudo"
were you able to grub-install (hd0) with success?
did you issue the following "sudo grub-install hd0"
in which prompt, normal or grub ? got too many windows open
in normal
http://paste.ubuntu.com/27163/ like that ?
yeah like that...but something is funny with your grub
if i were you i would just do the following "sudo apt-get install --reinstall grub"
ok lemme try
i assume that the computer that you are trying to fix is not the computer that you are logged into irc chat with

its funny because usually im the teaching guy (hardware/networking/windows), aint got much linux experience tho, last time I was using one was mandrake like 6yrs ago, appreciate your help alot :)  PS. its downloading some stuff now, will keep you reported
np@all.
http://paste.ubuntu.com/27164/ thats what I got
good grub has been installed from scratch
do you have a file called /boot/grub/menu.lst
can you also post me the output of mount command
last time i checked it it was empty, gonna check again, just gonna find the command
what do you mean find the command....you should simply be able to enter mount and get the output?
command to open the file, or what do you want me to do ?
well send the output of the "mount" command
also send me the contents of menu.lst file...you can do that by " cat /boot/grub/menu.lst "
http://paste.ubuntu.com/27165/
and that other command doesnt work
what does it say?
file doesn't exist or soemthing?
nvm used other command, it opened the file but its empty :S
issue the following command, incase you don't have read permission somehow : "sudo cat /boot/grub/menu.lst"
no such file or directory
is that the output of the sudo cat /boot/grub/menu.lst command?
also, can you send me the output of the following command "sudo mount -a & mount"
also send me the output of : "cat /etc/fstab"
http://paste.ubuntu.com/27167/
send me the output of /etc/fstab file.
please send the output of "mount" command once again please
http://paste.ubuntu.com/27168/ thats the mount, not sure how do i do the other one
cat /etc/fstab
when you mounted all your partitions, the most important of all partitions, /, wasn't mounted
http://paste.ubuntu.com/27169/ here u go
i think you have some serious issues with your /etc/fstab file
how can your fstab file be so dry?
did you install a new harddisk after installing ubuntu or something?
dont ask me, no idea if it helps but i couldnt get win xp to install on this earlier as well
well i tried to install it few times, maybe thats why
i don't think that you actually successfully installed ubuntu...or did you?
I did, then it asks you to restart after installation, after that reboot I  got that grub error i posted at the begini
grub stage 1.5 read error , to be exact
tried reinstalling 2 times, then i just started from live cd and came here
so right now you are running off livecd?
you need to mount your harddrive first, then you need to give me your /etc/fstab file
how do i do that ?
you said i have to mount hdd first and then check that whatever file

yes, right now you are running an OS based completely off the livecd,.... your harddrve doesn't enter the equation at all. the settings that i was asking you for pertain to your harddive - which isn't in the equation at all.
so we need to bring your harddisk into the equation first...you can do this by issuing the following : sudo mkdir /media/harddrive && mount /dev/hda3 /media/harddrive
for the second command you will need to insert a "sudo " immediately after the "&&" symbol.
mkdir: cannot create direectory '/media/harddrive' : File exists
so u are doing a brand new install?
you need at bare minimum 1 swap partition and one "/" parition
i would recommend 1 swap , 1 "/" partition, and one /home partition so that next time in case you have to reformat everything you won't lose your dloads and other precious stuff like that.
190gb, 1gb ram
set up 2gigs swap partition, and the remaining space (assuming you want to use entire hdisk) as "/" partition with ext3 format.
kyncani : and that should be the simplest install possible
i got this 2gb swap, lets say I want to have 2 partitions, which ones do I make ?
if you want 2 partitions i would recommend that you have 130 gigs devoted to /home partition and the remaining to / parition
so next time you hit a roadblock that kills your system you can reinstall OS without having to worry about losing your settings and dloads in /home dir
it doesnt say in this software anything like where its mounted
are you using gparted or the install process ?
it should refer to "mount point" or something
what are you options under filesystem setting
do you see /home
do you see /home, among other entries
in one of those settings under "NEW" you will see a  selection of /home /boot....and so on.
nothing like that
